references: The results for English to German and English to French are shown in Tables 2 and 2, respectively. Overall, context-aware models significantly improved accuracy, in both contrastive and generative evaluations for both language pairs. To assess whether these improvements correlate with a reduction in gender bias, we analysed these results in more details.

S3.T6.2.caption: Accuracy over masculine forms (EN-DE) Accuracy over masculine forms (EN-FR) Accuracy over feminine forms (EN-DE) Accuracy over feminine forms (EN-FR)
S3.T6.2.table:
Contrast. Gen. Gen.
Correct (↑↑\uparrow↑) Incorrect (↓↓\downarrow↓)
Sent-level 92.00% 71.09% 5.64%
2to1 91.45% 67.27% 6.73%
Contrast. Gen. Gen.
Correct (↑↑\uparrow↑) Incorrect (↓↓\downarrow↓)
Sent-level 92.55% 76.91% 6.00%
2to1 96.36% 77.09% 4.73%
Contrast. Gen. Gen.
Correct (↑↑\uparrow↑) Incorrect (↓↓\downarrow↓)
Sent-level 16.36% 4.91% 66.73%
2to1 47.09% 22.91% 47.82%
Contrast. Gen. Gen.
Correct (↑↑\uparrow↑) Incorrect (↓↓\downarrow↓)
Sent-level 14.21% 8.93% 72.86%
2to1 42.08% 29.69% 51.18%
references:
We manually divided the test into two subsets based on the expected gender and calculated accuracy for each category, with the results shown in Tables 6 to 6.
The high scores in the masculine category, and the low scores in the feminine category, in both language pairs with the sentence-level baselines, suggest a significant bias in the data, causing the models to predominantly translate professions into the masculine form. Even when translating stereotypically feminine professions, the models generally tend to favour the masculine form as shown in Figure 1.

S3.T8.4.caption: Accuracy over gender-specific subsets (EN-DE) Accuracy over gender-specific subsets (EN-FR)
S3.T8.4.table:
Sentence-level Actual gender Context-aware Actual gender
Feminine Masculine Feminine Masculine
Stereot. Fem. 17.33% 88.67% Stereot. Fem. 56.00% (↑↑\uparrow↑ 38.67%) 89.33% (↑↑\uparrow↑ 0.66%)
Stereot. Masc. 18.00% 97.33% Stereot. Masc. 40.00% (↑↑\uparrow↑ 22.00%) 93.33% (↓↓\downarrow↓ 4.00%)
Sentence-level Actual gender Context-aware Actual gender
Feminine Masculine Feminine Masculine
Stereot. Fem. 21.33% 87.33% Stereot. Fem. 49.33% (↑↑\uparrow↑ 28.00%) 96.67% (↑↑\uparrow↑ 9.34%)
Stereot. Masc. 8.72% 97.33% Stereot. Masc. 30.87% (↑↑\uparrow↑ 22.15%) 97.33% (===)
references: We further analysed these results by focusing on professions categorised as stereotypically feminine or masculine, dividing the results into four subcategories based on the type of profession and the expected gender, and assessing accuracy using contrastive evaluation. Results in Tables 8 and 8 show that, for both language pairs, the largest gains from context originate from the feminine category as expected, but to a much larger degree for professions stereotypically seen as feminine.

S3.T9.1.caption: Contrastive accuracy on the parliamentary subsets of COH-TGT:GENDER (EU-ES)
S3.T9.1.table:
Total Masculine Feminine
Sentence-level 50% 90% 10%
2to1 50% 98% 2%
2to1∗ - ctxTED 50% 88% 12%
references: The contrastive evaluation results shown in Table 9 indicate that, as expected, the overall accuracy does not vary with or without context with uninformative context. However, when dividing the results by gender category, the accuracy for the masculine category increased to 98%, while the accuracy for the feminine category decreased from 10% to 2%. Using uninformative context actually increased gender bias in this case.

S3.T10.1.caption: Generative accuracy on the feminine parliamentary subset of COH-TGT:GENDER (EU-ES)
S3.T10.1.table:
Correct Incorrect
Sentence-level 4% 70%
2to1 0% 74%
2to1∗ - ctxTED 4% 70%
references: Additionally, we performed a generative evaluation over feminine forms only (Table 10). In line with the contrastive results, the sentence-level results indicate a clear tendency towards masculine translation in this domain, with 70% of incorrect instances in the feminine subset. The results also confirm that the use of context exacerbates this tendency, resulting in even fewer correct feminine forms translation.
